awd_titl_txt: The Last Glacial Termination in Southern Middle Latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
The spectacular termination that marked the end of the last major ice age represents the largest and most rapid natural climate change in Earth's recent history.  Identifying the conditions and processes that led to this termination requires detailed chronologies of sensitive paleoclimate proxies that monitor the last glacial/interglacial transition across the globe. This grant will develop such a chronology in the middle latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere for the reduction of ice volume in the Southern Alps of New Zealand from the last glacial maximum to today?s conditions. Our chronology will be based on newly developed state-of- the-art 10Be surface-exposure dating of glacial landforms produced during this reduction. This grant will  determine if the Antarctic deglacial signal extents to  middle latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere, thus setting up a test of a recent  hypothesis  that the Principal Investigator published in Science. The hypothesis posits that large Northern Hemisphere ice sheets, triggered by rising summer sunshine, produced a self-sustaining flood of icebergs and melt water into the North Atlantic, leading to cold northern stadial conditions that altered the global meridional temperature gradients which in turn regulated the major global zonal wind systems. A poleward shift and/or intensification of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies warms the Southern Hemisphere from middle latitudes to Antarctica and purges enough CO2 to the atmosphere by Southern Ocean upwelling to maintain interglacial conditions worldwide. Because New Zealand glaciers lie in middle latitudes near the outer boundary of the Southern Ocean, this hypothesis predicts that their volume loss should correlate with the Antarctic warming pulse and should be in antiphase with the northern stadial triggered by freshwater influx into the North Atlantic. This research will date ice recession in New Zealand?s Southern Alps and thus test this prediction.

Present-day global warming is front-page news. But scientists still do not fully understand the underlying mechanisms that caused the great global warming that ended the last ice age and produced the interglacial conditions of the last 11,700 years, during which human civilization and population has developed. The team has developed a hypothesis of how this great warming was achieved. The grant will produce knowledge of the timing of Southern Hemisphere events to test the hypothesis. This test involves recognition of changes in wind belts and ocean circulation that accompany a shift in the temperature gradient between hemispheres. A shift in the interhemispheric temperature gradient is also expected shortly, as rising atmospheric CO2 is predicted to warm the Southern less than the Northern Hemisphere.  Thus, by studying the past great warming,  we may be able to anticipate how such changes may occur during the ongoing global warming.

por.por_cntn:
This research inquired into the underlying reasons for the great global warming at the end of the last ice age that transformed Earth’s climate from glacial to interglacial conditions. At the glacial maximum, continental ice sheets covered large areas of the Northern Hemisphere. The reduction of this continental ice to about its present volume as the earth emerged from the last ice age represents the largest natural climate change in the planet’s recent history. Identifying the conditions and processes of the warming that brought the ice age to a close and produced the ongoing interglacial condition should afford insights into the more recent warming of the planet.

From 10Be surface-exposure and radiocarbon chronologies of glacier moraines in southern middle latitudes, and from comparison of the resulting records with climate events registered in the WAIS-Divide ice core in West Antarctica, we identified a striking shift from glacial-to-interglacial atmospheric temperature that terminated the last glaciation in much of the Southern Hemisphere.  A remarkable result is that such a fundamental shift was accomplished in the few centuries between 17,700 and 16,800 years ago. This southern warming had a rapidity, extent, and magnitude suggestive of a mode switch of the climate system, in which the ocean and atmosphere are susceptible to rapid reorganizations because they are linked together in a nonlinear fashion, for example as outlined by Broecker and Denton in 1989. Such a mode shift is similar to the prescient insights on ice ages made by Lorenz in 1975. Because it is characterized by coupled, time-dependent, nonlinear dynamics, the climate system may exhibit a property that Lorenz dubbed “almost-intransitive”. Such a system can switch abruptly from one state of behavior to another. On the time scale of an ice age, Lorenz suggested that the behavior of the earth’s climate system could have been “almost intransitive”, with the two first-order states being glacial and interglacial, and with the transformation, now called a termination, being short relative to the length of each state. Thus our most important result is that the atmospheric temperature signatures that we have derived from mid-latitude mountain glaciers in the Southern Hemisphere have a pattern compatible with the hypotheses of mode switches and almost-intransitive behavior of the global climate system.

We also carried out activities that had broader impacts. Several graduate and undergraduate students were supported on the project and gained significant field and laboratory experience. Data and photographs from the research have been used in undergraduate and graduate classes at the University of Maine and have been posted on our website. The major outreach was an American Museum of Natural History documentary of our research that was shown on the great wall of the AMNH and at 32 other museums in North America and Europe (Shrinking Glaciers, now on the AMNH website). The number of viewers of such documentaries is estimated by the AMNH at 7-10 million.
